title: How to Make Stuffed Pancakes

steps.headline: Place 6 to 7 dollops of Nutella onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
steps.description: Use 1½ to 2 tablespoons (28.5 to 38 grams) of Nutella per drop. This recipe is enough to make 6 to 7 pancakes, but it might be a good idea to make a few dollops of Nutella in case one breaks. If you can't find any parchment paper, you can use wax paper instead. If you don't like Nutella, you can try other fillings as well, such as peanut butter or jam. Consider mixing flavors. Try half a dollop of peanut butter and half a dollop of jelly.

steps.headline: Spread the dollops into disks.
steps.description: The disks need to be about 2½ inches (6 centimeters) wide and ¼-inches (½-centimeter) thick. You can use a spoon or rubber spatula to do this.

steps.headline: Freeze the disks until they turn solid.
steps.description: It will take about 60 to 90 minutes for them to freeze. Once they are solid, peel them off of the parchment paper, then store them in the freezer.

steps.headline: Whisk together the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Measure the flour into a large mixing bowl. Add the baking powder, sugar, and salt. Stir everything together until everything is combined and no clumps remain.

steps.headline: Stir the wet ingredients into the dry ones.
steps.description: Pat down the dry mixture first, then make a hole in the center. Pour the milk into the hole, then add the egg and vanilla extract. Stir everything together with a whisk until smooth. Be careful not to over-mix, or the pancakes will turn out tough and chewy.

steps.headline: Melt some butter in a non-stick pan, then wipe it off.
steps.description: Place the pan over the stove and add ½ teaspoon of butter. Allow the butter to melt, then wipe most of it away with a paper towel.

steps.headline: Take out 2 to 3 Nutella disks.
steps.description: Leave the rest in the freezer. The next few steps will go by quickly but Nutella melts quickly. If you take all of the disks out, they will melt before you get to use them.

steps.headline: Add some batter into the pan.
steps.description: You will need to use ¼ cup (60 milliliters) of batter per pancake. If your pan is large enough, you may be able to fit two pancakes.

steps.headline: Place a Nutella disk on top of each pancake.
steps.description: Make sure that the disks are centered. Working with frozen Nutella disks is much easier than working with soft Nutella.

steps.headline: Top each pancake off with more batter.
steps.description: This time around, you only need to use enough batter to cover the Nutella disk. Use the edge of a spook or spatula to help spread the batter over the Nutella. Work quickly because the disk will start to melt once it's in the pancake.

steps.headline: Flip the pancake when the bubbles appear.
steps.description: After about 2 minutes, bubbles will start to form around the edges. Use a spatula to lift the pancake up and check the underside. If it is golden, carefully flip the pancake over.

steps.headline: Continue cooking the pancake until it is golden.
steps.description: This will take another minute or so. When the pancake is golden on both sides, slide it off of the pan and onto a plate. If Nutella oozes out onto the pan, wipe it off. If you don't, you'll end up with Nutella on the next pancake.

steps.headline: Make the rest of the pancakes.
steps.description: After the third or fourth pancake, you will need to add more butter to the pan. Remember to wipe the butter off. You should be able to make at least 6 pancakes, but you might be able to make 7.

steps.headline: Serve the pancakes.
steps.description: They taste great with sliced strawberries. If you want to you could even add some whipped cream!

steps.headline: Separate the yolks from the whites.
steps.description: Beat the egg whites until they turn stiff, then set them aside. You will eventually be folding them into the batter. You can also make pancake batter from a mix instead. If you choose to make your pancake batter from a box instead, use less water and/or milk than required. This will give you a thicker batter that is easier to work with.

steps.headline: Combine the yolks, sugar, salt, and baking powder.
steps.description: Beat together the yolks, sugar, and salt first until everything is smooth and consistent and not streaks remain. Stir in the baking powder until just combined.

steps.headline: Add in the flour, milk, oil, and vanilla extract.
steps.description: Keep whisking until the batter is smooth. It will be a little lumpy, which is fine. Don't try to beat these out or you will over-mix the batter. This could lead to tough and chewy pancakes.

steps.headline: Fold in the egg whites.
steps.description: Use a rubber spatula to scrape the beaten egg whites into the bowl. Gently fold them in, scraping the bottom and sides of the bowl often. Keep folding until the color is consistent and no streaks remain.

steps.headline: Let the batter rest for 15 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: During this time, you can start preparing the bacon. By the time the bacon is ready and cooled, the batter should be ready too.

steps.headline: Fry the bacon in a griddle over medium-high heat.
steps.description: Wipe the excess grease from the pan when you are done. This way, you won't have to re-grease the pan for the pancakes. If you don't have a griddle, you can use a skillet instead. Keep in mind that you will have to make the pancakes in smaller batches later on.

steps.headline: Set the bacon aside on some paper towels.
steps.description: This will help soak up the excess grease and make the bacon even crispier. Once the extra grease has been soaked up, you are ready to continue.

steps.headline: Place the bacon back onto the griddle.
steps.description: Leave about 2 inches (5 centimeters) of space between the each slice of bacon. If you turned the heat off on the griddle, turn it back to medium-high.

steps.headline: Pour the batter over each strip of bacon.
steps.description: Use a soup or sauce ladle to scoop up the batter and pour it over the bacon strips. The batter will ooze over the sizes of the bacon and give you rectangular pancakes.

steps.headline: Cook the pancakes.
steps.description: After 1 to 2 minutes, check the underside of the pancake. If it's golden brown, slide a spatula under it, flip it over, and continue cooking it. The pancakes are ready when they are golden brown on both sides.

steps.headline: Continue cooking the rest of the pancakes.
steps.description: As you finish making the pancakes, slide them off of the griddle and onto a plate. Depending on the size of your griddle or skillet, you may have to work in batches.

steps.headline: Serve the pancakes immediately.
steps.description: You can serve them as they are, or garnish them with some softened butter and/or warm maple syrup..

text: Making Nutella Stuffed Pancakes Place 6 to 7 dollops of Nutella onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Use 1½ to 2 tablespoons (28.5 to 38 grams) of Nutella per drop. If you don't like Nutella, you can try other fillings as well, such as peanut butter or jam. Consider mixing flavors. Try half a dollop of peanut butter and half a dollop of jelly. Spread the dollops into disks. The disks need to be about 2½ inches (6 centimeters) wide and ¼-inches (½-centimeter) thick. You can use a spoon or rubber spatula to do this. Stir everything together with a whisk until smooth. Be careful not to over-mix, or the pancakes will turn out tough and chewy. Melt some butter in a non-stick pan, then wipe it off. Place the pan over the stove and add ½ teaspoon of butter. Allow the butter to melt, then wipe most of it away with a paper towel. Take out 2 to 3 Nutella disks. Leave the rest in the freezer. The next few steps will go by quickly but Nutella melts quickly. If you take all of the disks out, they will melt before you get to use them. Add some batter into the pan. You will need to use ¼ cup (60 milliliters) of batter per pancake. If your pan is large enough, you may be able to fit two pancakes. Place a Nutella disk on top of each pancake. Make sure that the disks are centered. Working with frozen Nutella disks is much easier than working with soft Nutella. Top each pancake off with more batter. This time around, you only need to use enough batter to cover the Nutella disk. Use the edge of a spook or spatula to help spread the batter over the Nutella. Work quickly because the disk will start to melt once it's in the pancake. Flip the pancake when the bubbles appear. After about 2 minutes, bubbles will start to form around the edges. Use a spatula to lift the pancake up and check the underside. If it is golden, carefully flip the pancake over. Continue cooking the pancake until it is golden. This will take another minute or so. When the pancake is golden on both sides, slide it off of the pan and onto a plate. If Nutella oozes out onto the pan, wipe it off. If you don't, you'll end up with Nutella on the next pancake. Make the rest of the pancakes. After the third or fourth pancake, you will need to add more butter to the pan. Remember to wipe the butter off. Making Bacon Stuffed Pancakes Separate the yolks from the whites. Beat the egg whites until they turn stiff, then set them aside. You will eventually be folding them into the batter. You can also make pancake batter from a mix instead. If you choose to make your pancake batter from a box instead, use less water and/or milk than required. This will give you a thicker batter that is easier to work with. Combine the yolks, sugar, salt, and baking powder. Beat together the yolks, sugar, and salt first until everything is smooth and consistent and not streaks remain. Stir in the baking powder until just combined. Add in the flour, milk, oil, and vanilla extract. Keep whisking until the batter is smooth. It will be a little lumpy, which is fine. Don't try to beat these out or you will over-mix the batter. This could lead to tough and chewy pancakes. Fold in the egg whites. Use a rubber spatula to scrape the beaten egg whites into the bowl. Gently fold them in, scraping the bottom and sides of the bowl often. Keep folding until the color is consistent and no streaks remain. Let the batter rest for 15 to 30 minutes. During this time, you can start preparing the bacon. By the time the bacon is ready and cooled, the batter should be ready too. Fry the bacon in a griddle over medium-high heat. Wipe the excess grease from the pan when you are done. This way, you won't have to re-grease the pan for the pancakes. If you don't have a griddle, you can use a skillet instead. Keep in mind that you will have to make the pancakes in smaller batches later on. Set the bacon aside on some paper towels. This will help soak up the excess grease and make the bacon even crispier. Once the extra grease has been soaked up, you are ready to continue. Place the bacon back onto the griddle. Leave about 2 inches (5 centimeters) of space between the each slice of bacon. If you turned the heat off on the griddle, turn it back to medium-high. Pour the batter over each strip of bacon. Use a soup or sauce ladle to scoop up the batter and pour it over the bacon strips. The batter will ooze over the sizes of the bacon and give you rectangular pancakes. Cook the pancakes. After 1 to 2 minutes, check the underside of the pancake. If it's golden brown, slide a spatula under it, flip it over, and continue cooking it. The pancakes are ready when they are golden brown on both sides. Continue cooking the rest of the pancakes. As you finish making the pancakes, slide them off of the griddle and onto a plate. Depending on the size of your griddle or skillet, you may have to work in batches. Serve the pancakes immediately. You can serve them as they are, or garnish them with some softened butter and/or warm maple syrup..
